plist.p: Good morning everyone and welcome. Thank you for joining us today. I'd like to start by formally welcoming Laurie McIlwee to his first preliminary results meeting. Laurie's been with Tesco for some nine years now. He has a very strong track record in both finance and in operations as our distribution Director, where he was responsible for transforming our network, a tremendous achievement. His appointment shows once again how careful management succession works in Tesco and I have every confidence he'll do a great job for us as Group Finance Director and take it on from a long line of excellent Finance Directors over the years.

We've also appointed three strong new Non-Executive Directors in recent months. Jacqueline Tammenoms Bakker, a former Director General at the Ministry of Transport in the Netherlands who's also held senior positions at McKinsey and Shell. Also very well known Patrick Cescau, former CEO of Unilever and Ken Hanna also joins us, a Chairman of Inchcape and former CFO of Cadbury. They bring with them a wealth of international commercial and financial experience and this will further strengthen the Board, and support our plans for the long-term growth of the Group.
So today we'll follow our usual running order with Laurie covering the financial results, followed by Terry with an update on strategy and we'll then be happy to take your questions.

I'm pleased to report that despite the extraordinary economic environment we find ourselves in Tesco has once again delivered a good set of results. This demonstrates that Tesco is coping well with the downturn. Despite the challenging conditions around the globe we've remained resilient, and we're growing as fast as any major international retailer. Whilst the downturn has presented many challenges it has also opened up some opportunities.

As you know, we've made two very significant acquisitions during the year. In South Korea we purchased 36 hypermarkets from E-Land mostly in Seoul, which has now put us in a very strong position to challenge for market leadership in one of our most successful markets. We've also bought the remaining 50% of Tesco Personal Finance from RBS, a move which will enable us to develop our already successful financial services offer towards our objective of becoming a full service retail bank.

Most of our growth has again been organic. We've opened 9 million square feet of new space this year excluding the acquisition in Korea. In August we announced our entry into India with plans to establish a cash-and-carry operation and a franchise agreement with Trent to support their Star Bazaar hypermarkets, and this complements our entries into China and also the United States and giving us access to another of the world's most important economies.

Whilst many of our customers are focused on managing their shopping baskets, it's still important to them that we behave responsibly particularly in the communities we serve. We now have a plan for each country and earlier in the year we launched our community promises. These are actively supporting local communities, buying and selling our products responsibly, caring for the environment and giving customers healthy choices and creating good jobs and careers.

We've made some great progress this year. We've opened our greenest ever store at Cheetham Hill in Manchester with a carbon footprint some 70% smaller than a typical store, bringing our total number of green stores across the globe to 37. And these will be used as blue prints for how we build stores in the future.

Our work to encourage customers to make greener decisions is going well. Through Green Club card points we've reduced the number of single use carrier bags in the UK by 50% now and we're also finding innovative ways to use Green Club cards elsewhere. For example in Korea they're rewarding customers for cycling to our stores, very healthy.

I'm also pleased to announce that in the UK we've once again broken our Charity of the Year record with an incredible 6.2 million raised for Marie Curie Cancer Care. Although it was impossible to predict the scale of the global economic slowdown, Tesco is responding well, by adjusting our business to this environment. Our 470,000-strong team are doing a great job, staying close to customers and reacting quickly to their changing needs.

So I am confident that their hard work will continue as we sensibly press on with our long-term strategy, which I believe will put us in an even stronger position once the economies start to recover. That's all from me, I'll now hand you over to Laurie to take you through the financials.

Thank you David for that warm welcome and good morning everyone. First, I'd like to outline the main financial headlines for the Group. We've delivered solid growth in sales, profit, and earnings in a challenging trading environment. We've continued to invest in our strategy including the acquisitions of TPF and Homever.

Our productivity program continues to make substantial cost savings and the business is delivering for shareholders with strong earnings growth. This is allowing for good, well-covered dividend growth. We have a strong property-backed balance sheet with no liquidity or refinancing issues. This year we plan to maintain good organic space growth whilst managing our CapEx well below our cash generation.

I'll now go through the detail of our Group performance. This year has been a 53-week financial year for the UK, Ireland, and the United States and for ease of comparison and where appropriate I'll highlight the 52-week growth rates. Total Group sales for the year ending the 28th of February 2009 were 59.4 billion up 15.1%, and on a 52-week basis sales were up 13.5%. Group trading profit rose by 12.4% to 3.09 billion. Profit is stated after initial trading losses for Fresh & Easy and Homever integration costs. Before these, the Group trading profit rose by 16.1%.

Group underlying profit before tax was 3.13 billion, up 10% with growth being impacted by an increased interest charge. Group property profits have increased by 26% from 188 million to 236 million this year. Although conditions in the wider property market have deteriorated there remains good appetite for Tesco property and covenants.

We're in discussions with a view to completing further divestments in the months ahead at attractive yields, and the proceeds from the deals we do this year will be used to pay down our debt. Some 80% of the Group property remains freehold. And we currently estimate the market value of our freehold property assets to be around £30 billion.

Group pre-tax profit is up 5.5%, and the lower growth rate is principally due to the IAS 32 and 39, effects of which move from being a credit of 49 million in 2007 into a debit of 88 million this year. The IAS 32 and 39 Standards relate principally to non-cash mark-to-market adjustments, which can be very volatile.

Underlying diluted earnings per share were up 7% to 28.92 pence, with good growth despite the exceptionally low tax rate last year linked to the rebate from HMRC. Using a constant tax rate and based on 52-weeks, underlying diluted earnings per share were up 9.7%. The proposed final dividend is 8.39 pence, up 9% and this gives a full year dividend of 11.96 pence, up 9.7%. This is consistent with our policy of growing annual dividend policy in line with underlying diluted EPS on constant tax rates.

I'm now going to take you through the performance of the UK. Total sales in the UK were up 9.5% to 41.5 billion. Like-for-like sales were 4.3%, new stores contributed 2.7%, the 53rd week added 2.1% and the contribution from TPF was 0.4%. Ex-petrol, like-for-like was 3% for the year and UK ex-petrol, like-for-like in the last seven weeks of the year was 2.1% or 3.1% ex-VAT. And for the first six weeks of this year like-for-like has improved to 3.4% or 4.4% ex-VAT.

We've seen inflation in our stores during the year and the falling sterling will ensure that inflation is more prolonged. Offsetting inflation in our business has been the mix effect of customers down-trading. Our physical volumes have however grown well.

Last year's UK trading profit included the startup costs of Fresh & Easy. This year we are reporting the United States separately within the International segment. So we've restated last year's comparative numbers. UK trading profit was 2.38 billion up 12.7% on a 52-week basis and the UK trading profit was up 10.7%. UK trading margin was 6.2%, an increase of 17 basis points on last year, and this included a small contribution from TPF in the two months since it was consolidated, and I'll come back to this in a moment.

Increased investment in pricing and promotions and other improvements in the shopping trip were funded from £540 million worth of step-change. This has been delivered through long-term productivity projects ranging from energy savings to supply chain initiatives. Apparently distribution did very well. .

Total sales were 17.9 billion, up 30.6% at actual exchange rates and 13.6% at constant rates, and international sales excluding Fresh & Easy and Homever were up 26.7%. International trading profits before Fresh & Easy and the initial losses of Homever integration costs were up 26.6% at actual rates and by 13.3% at constant rates. On this basis, international trading margins were unchanged.

In Asia sales were 7.6 billion up 29.4% at actual rates and by 19.9% at constant rates. Excluding Homever, sales were up 23.5% at actual rates. Trading profit in Asia rose to 355 million before the effect of consolidating Homever, which was loss making at the acquisition. Trading profit increased by 28.9% at actual rates and 26.2% at constant rates. Margins were strong, driven by good performances in Malaysia and Thailand.

Helped by favorable exchange rates in Europe sales rose by 29.1% to 10.1 billion, and increased by 6.9% at constant rates. We've seen some deteriorating demand in some Europe markets particularly the Republic of Ireland, the Czech and Slovak Republics. Linked to the economic environment and to an increase in cross-border shopping into neighboring countries and recently we've seen some stabilization in consumer confidence in Europe following the financial shocks of last autumn. Trading profit rose to 496 million, an increase of 24.9% at actual rates and 3.50% at constant rates.

Fresh & Easy, sales were 208 million with like-for-like sales growth of 30%. At constant exchange rates the trading loss was 123 million. Higher than our guidance at the beginning of the year and this was due to the severity of the economic downturn, but also our decision to maintain and not accelerate our new store openings.

We're excited about our opportunities in Retail Services and we'll be organizing a dedicated services seminar in the next few months to bring you up to speed with our plans and so that you can meet the team that's actually doing the work. Total retailing services sales we 3.4 billion, up 11% on last year and trading profits were 460 million, up 21%. We're delighted to have completed the acquisition of Tesco Personal Finance in December, but clearly it's been a turbulent time for the financial services sector. But TPF has a high quality book, no toxic assets and a strong liquidity.

The bad debt experience is better than the industry average and the acquisition has allowed us to make even more prudent provisions for bad debts going forward. In these accounts TPF is included as a joint venture for 50 weeks to the 19th of December, and is included for a subsidiary for the 10 weeks to the 28th of February year end. For ease of comparison and to give you a base for your numbers next year we published a TPF pro forma income statement for the year ending February 2009 and you'll find this in the press release. On this basis underlying profits before tax were 244 million.

Insurance is over 65% of the profits, the remainder of the profits have come from our banking products, mainly credit cards, with a stable income stream from our ATM network. We've had tremendous success with our saving products attracting over 100,000 new customers in the last four months of the year and growing our saving book to over £4.5 billion. We turned the year -- we ended the year with a balance sheet in net surplus and we're investing prudently in UK treasury bills and short-term investments.

TPF is well capitalized; our core tier 1 ratio is 12%. That's significantly better than our banking peer group. We've provided a balance sheet in the press release if you'd like to see more detail. Profits from joint ventures and associates were 110 million up from 75 million last year. And this year's number includes 50 weeks profit from Tesco Personal Finance while it was a joint venture.

Tax has been charged at 26.7% reflecting the new lower Corporation Tax rate, which came into effect in April 2008. This year we also expect the tax rate to be around 27%. Our net debt rose to 9.6 billion from 6.2 billion a year ago with an increase largely reflecting our capital outlay of 6.6 billion in the year.

Last July we talked about a target net debt figure of around 8 billion. We said at the time, that this assumes stable sterling and a level of property proceeds. And, of course, we've seen significant depreciation in sterling causing a debt impact of approximately £1 billion. We've also been careful to manage the flow of property deals into the market and reducing the levels of proceeds compared to earlier plans.

And given the strength of our operating cash flow our debt is eminently manageable, but it's higher than I would like. And that's why in the current year we'll bring it back down to approximately 8.5 billion. We'll do this through a combination of lower CapEx and property proceeds and it's of course reliant upon stable exchange rates again and the success of our property sales.

After the 2 billion bond issue in February, our average debt maturity has moved to 11 years. We have 2.7 billion of undrawn backup liquidity facilities and 75% of our debt is now fixed. The weighted average coupon is 5.6% and we've only 300 million of bonds maturing in this financial year. So we've no liquidity or financing issues.

Net finance costs have increased to 362 million, which includes the net returns on pension schemes assets and liabilities in addition to the impact of IAS 32 and 39. The underlying interest rate charge has increased to 309 million from 159 million last year and that's driven principally by the increase in net debt.

Moving on to pensions, we're proud to continue offering an award-winning defined-benefit pension scheme and our staff tell us it's very important to them. To ensure this scheme remains in good health, the trustees determine the funding using prudent actuarial assumptions. The trustees have completed their independent review of funding as part of the triennial valuation and as expected it showed a small deficit of 275 million.

Following this valuation we agreed to increase the member and company contribution rates to 0.7% of salary, ensuring the scheme remains in a good position. As you know for accounting purposes IFRS requires that we re-value the pension scheme liabilities on our high quality corporate bond yield. The IFRS pension deficit is 1.1 billion after-tax, which is broadly the same as we reported in September.

Group capital expenditure during the year was 4.7 billion. This was a little ahead of our expectations of up to 4.5 billion due to currency movements. Total international capital rose to 2.1 billion, comprising of 0.9 billion in Europe, 0.9 billion in Asia and 0.3 billion in the US. Total capital expenditure in the UK rose to 2.6 billion from 2.3 billion last year, and mainly as a result of the purchase of a small number of trading stores from a competitor and investment in new mixed-use development schemes in the UK. This year we expect Group capital expenditure to be around 3.5 billion.

We can reduce CapEx whilst maintaining good growth in organic space for two main reasons. First the bulge in the UK CapEx we've seen over the last couple of years has gone through, and doesn't need to be repeated. Second, in this environment we can buy for less. Our CapEx can go further because site, build, and fit-out costs are all falling.

Operating cash flow was 5 billion, up from 4.1 billion last year and 0.3 billion higher than CapEx. This increase is due to improved profits from our core operations and a 0.6 billion improvement in working capital, partly as a result of the improvement in stock controls. Adjusting for new investment TPF and Homever this year our Group return on capital employed was slightly up at 13%.

In summary, we've delivered a solid performance both in the UK and overseas and we're confident that good profit growth will continue in the current year, particularly with the benefits of our two acquisitions coming through. Thank you. I'll now hand over to Terry.

Thanks Laurie, and good morning everyone. Well these results demonstrate that Tesco has again made good progress despite facing into some strong headwinds. Sales and profits have grown solidly, returns have held up well, and the growth has come from right across the Group.

Now, I'm pleased about that for several reasons. First, because it shows that our strategy is the right one for sustaining growth even through this downturn. Second, because our businesses are adjusting their models and approach successfully to meet the needs of a different customer, that's one with less money to spend. And third because it underlines the strength of Tesco, that we can do these things, deliver the numbers and yet still carry the substantial investment today in tomorrow's growth, whether it's in Financial Services, China, Korea, or the US.

It's not been easy, but we've come through in good shape and that's not an accident. I believe we've coped well because we anticipated the challenges and the opportunities and set the business up to tackle both. Getting ahead early and staying ahead on costs finding the necessary investment to help customers spend less, seeing the openings to buy good assets well, these are I think clear evidence of the right approach.

And going forward, we've got some big self-help projects this year to support our growth. We're doing more on the international buying, we're delivering sizable benefits from recent acquisitions, and we're becoming self-reliant in terms of funding our own expansion to pay down debt and drive returns as Laurie spoke about.

At times like this, the most important thing for a business like Tesco to do is to stay close to customers, keep them shopping with us, make sure volumes are strong, and I'm pleased to say that's what we're doing. Of course, there is more to do and in some areas we can do better. But I'm confident that this focus will see us through the tough times and ensure that we're even better positioned for when the upturn comes.

I'll begin my usual update this morning with International, where we've made very good progress overall against the background of weakening demand. Sales increased strongly up by 31% in the year. Of course exchange rates helped particularly in Europe, as did the Homever acquisition in Asia. And profits advanced well, up 22% excluding the US and margins were remarkably resilient despite the short-term effect of acquiring the Korean stores.

So it's been very pleasing as an overall performance in the year, but the effects of a slowing global economy are now to be seen everywhere. Europe felt the effects earliest and harder actually, they early summer, spring, early summer last year it began in Europe.

The impact in Asia was delayed, but it's there now, with the export-led countries feeling the strain from global destocking signs. Asia really started to feel it November-December through up until the present time. The US too, particularly in the western former boom states, is dealing with a sharp contraction. There too it really started in a very severe way May last year and then really took a big step-down with the banking crisis in the autumn.

My message to you is that Tesco is dealing with the obvious challenges this poses for all companies. You can see from today's trading update we're still driving good growth from our international businesses. We're well prepared and we've a strong plan to deliver further growth in sales and in profits this year.

I'm pleased with our performance across Central Europe. Customer numbers are continuing to grow. Market share growth has actually accelerated. These numbers show this well. They demonstrate how our market positions have been strengthening in all four countries and strategically this is important because others too of course feel the strain. Our resolve to push on through this tough period will see us emerging even stronger.

In general non-food, has been a tougher market across our network internationally for understandable reasons, but in some areas we've showed what our size and global reach can deliver. For example, clothing sales in Central Europe have been very good, up 11% in a very difficult year there and indeed in the new financial year, the new ranges, sales growth has increased by 25%.

Progress in Central Europe has been helped by strong results in Hungary. Now you'll remember we had big problems in Hungary there, but our strategy of investing hard in our offer for customers, keeping costs low, expanding our store base, it's given us momentum to grow sales and profits, even through a prolonged, probably three year long now, recession in Hungary. And this will be a model for how we run our European operations during the wider downturn.

Czech, Slovakia, and particularly Poland, all grew strongly; helped by the growing maturity and profitability of our smaller format stores and they will be the focus of our expansion. In Poland, sales in the Leader Price stores are now up 60% since conversion. In fact our smaller format stores in Poland grew like-for-like actually faster than Biedronka in the fourth quarter, which is quite a turn around.

Elsewhere in Europe, Ireland did well in a very difficult market, helped by a strong store opening program of course. Thailand achieved another impressive year, against a background of political instability. Our Talad and Express formats grew particularly strongly. We saw a promising first profit from Financial Services there too.

Growth in Malaysia has again been excellent. And now just seven years since opening our first stores there, we're now highly profitable; market leading business. So we're already the market leader and the fastest growing. The Makro acquisition has been a great success. It's fully integrated now and going forward we can sustain good organic growth; seven large hypermarkets opening this year.

Introducing Clubcard and Dunnhumby in Malaysia has been a key to sustained success through improved customer insight and we're, gradually as these businesses get to scale, rolling out Clubcard and Dunnhumby in other countries in China, Korea, Ireland as well as pilots in Thailand, Slovakia, Poland and Turkey. So you can see that over the next couple of years Clubcard and Dunnhumby will be a standard part of the package.

In Japan the already difficult retail market has worsened. But the new team there has made good progress helped by the new benefits from – I've got the notes the wrong way around. I was about to tell you that Japan had benefited from the new DC in Dublin. But I won't. I could have said it and you'd have just nodded. Helped by the rollout of our new 24-hour Express stores in Tokyo, Japan.

China we've begun to push on with faster regional expansion, we're based in three regions now, three of the five, and we're building large freehold shopping centers. And now the first -- they're actually being built now, the first of four of those opened this year, so it's a very, very important year for us in China, and we've got a further 14 of those in the development pipeline. We're looking to involve external investors in sharing the capital required to build such a network of stores, and we believe they will be a model for how to retail profitably in China in the long-term.

Flicking back through the notes, our Korean business of course, saw record sales and profits growth in the core business and despite the distraction of the integration of the Homever stores. But the Homever store conversions are complete now, they've gone extremely well, and we're seeing average sales uplifts of 50%.

The slides are not quite coping with me doing the presentation beginning at the end and going gradually to the front. So our focus on building stronger positions in our existing markets mainly through organic growth will take on even more strategic importance for two reasons. First our strength means we can sustain, we can stick at it, the expansion, through these tough times when others have to give up a bit, and that helps us to make relative progress.

And second, our money goes further. We can build stores far more cheaply today than just a few years ago. Capital costs per square foot of development coming down by well over 20%. So money goes further and that means higher returns. And it was the same picture in the last recession in the early 90s.

We opened over 7 million square feet of new space in International this year through organic growth so that excludes the acquisitions. This year even with a slower pace in some markets, where it makes sense to slow down the rate of growth because instead of growing, the markets are shrinking, we'll still open another 6 million square feet. And that's three quarters of our total space growth that will take place in International.

Finally, on International, I want to update you on CROIs. Our usual bubble chart is in the back of your pack. This chart shows the overall CROIs. Now given the impact of the economic downturn and the big step-up in CapEx right into the downturn over the last couple of years, CROIs have come down a little as you can see. I believe it's a good performance in this environment. Going forward, the economies will recover. The growing scale and maturity of our business will develop. I'm confident that we'll resume an upward path on our CROIs.

Before moving on to the UK, I want to update you on Fresh & Easy in the United States. Overall, I'm very pleased with the promising start we've made. We've built the business we wanted to create. I see plenty of encouraging signs. The response of customers to our offer continues to surpass expectations, of which we poll on a very, very regular basis. The latest polls are by far the best we have received even in the areas where we knew we had a potential weakness in terms of one-stop shopping and clear price communication. They understand the format. They love the fresh foods, the prices, and the neighborhood locations.

Now the changed environment in the Western United States means that it's not yet prudent to accelerate the rate of openings as we'd originally planned. Essentially these were boom cities putting on population growth, growing whole new neighborhoods. They've gone completely into reverse. People are leaving the cities, as unemployment goes, as foreclosures take place. So you haven't got markets to expand into as we had planned for the moment.

So, we're holding back on property. We've got plans for 60 to 70 stores this year. It means that trading losses will be similar to the year just ended. We could reduce them if we wish to, but I think it's important that we keep pushing on into the recession to keep the momentum up and that gives us a strong growing platform for when the returns -- when the upturn comes, which it will in those cities, it'll happen, but it will take a little bit of time.

As usual with any new format we've changed some things based on feedback. For example, we've added some promotions. We've put some more range into some categories such as grocery, frozen. We've introduced a warmer ambiance to the stores. We're also adding bigger packs in certain categories and more affordable price points in others, such as our 98-cent produce pack for budget conscious customers. Customers like the changes that have taken place.

Like-for-like sales increased by 30% in the year, and that's with very heavy self-impacts as we've build out networks in relatively confined spaces like Las Vegas or parts of Arizona. And customer numbers per store per week are increasing actually by more than that amount, across all 115 stores. Customer transactions are up by over a third compared with a year ago.

So to sum up, Internationals had a very good year. I'm particularly pleased that we sustained strong growth through the economic shocks of the last year and I'm confident that we're well positioned to make further progress in the year ahead.

I'd now like to turn to the UK, where it hasn't been easy, but where we've made progress and produced solid results. We've done good work on improving the shopping trip for customers. I'm very please about that. We've delivered excellent productivity, good margin control and I'll talk a bit more about this in a minute, because there's more to come. We've also done well I believe in non-food in a difficult market.

Where we aim to do better is in our overall like-for-like performance. We've deliberately taken a different path, actually helping customers to trade down in our stores as they buy our discount and related ranges. This reduces our inflation and like-for-like in the short term, but it builds customer traffic. It retains loyalty, which will improve our relative performance going forward. It's been the right thing to do. It's kept customers shopping with us. It's reversed the trend against the discounters and it's also giving us good volumes.

There's more to do, but as you can see from today's Trading Update we've seen some improvements in our like-for-like. Now going forward as always our focus will be on investing to improve the shopping trip. And I want to highlight a few things we're doing on price, Clubcard, range, service and availability.

Our price position is strong. We've improved it again. We're telling customers about it with price comparison advertising and at the shelf edge. It's important to win the communication war on price. But more important than that, more important even than price is building loyalty. And in this, Clubcard is unique in its ability to reward loyal behavior. Clubcard is being re-launched in the next few weeks with a substantial increased investment behind it to reward our loyal customers and to encourage one-stop shopping.

I'm delighted with our Discounter ranges. They're now in 30% of baskets and that's remarkable. In just six months for a range, that relative to all the things we sell is still a pretty narrow range. And they've made a real contribution to helping customers spend less. And at the same time sales of value lines are also up by a third.

The work we've done on checkout service, which we now measure very accurately, has delivered one in front to a million more customers a week. On shelf availability improved again. In fact it hit a record high just last week. And we've achieved some of our best ever results in recent weeks. For example produce gaps have fallen 20%. We've seen similar percentage improvements on fresh as a whole on the evening availability, which is always an area that's bothered us.

Our step-change program, which is into its twelfth year, funds these investments. Savings last year were 540 million. We plan to deliver similar savings this year. These arise mainly from large-scale changes to the way we do business. Examples include the reduction in distribution costs as a percentage of sales last year due to the complete reconfiguration of our UK DC network over the last three years. And that's been achieved despite higher fuel costs.

Energy consumption in total fell by 8% last year, that's in absolute terms the lowest level for five years. So we've absorbed all the growth in the business over the last five years and we're losing less energy in total than five years ago. We've spent some capital to do that. So with new refrigeration systems, store lobbies, new lighting systems, we'll be saving another 100 million this year from further reductions in energy use and of course lower energy prices. So that's quite a big help to the P&L in this year.

We now have 3,000 employees at our global support center in Bangalore, it provides Group economies of scale on IT, admin support to our UK and International operations from software developments to managing, accounting and payroll. New checkout technology has continued to reduced costs and improve customer service; 25% of our UK transactions are now through self-service checkouts.

I'm pleased with our progress in non-food against a headwind of a much more cautious consumer spending. Sales grew, market share increased, we managed our stock well, and we maintained profitability. In the UK our efforts to lower prices and to grow our business in key categories such as Electricals and Clothing and Entertainment helped sales to increase by 5%. Volume growth was higher actually at 9% driven by price decreases in certain categories.

Like-for-like sales have held up well, in complete contrast of course to the performance reported elsewhere in the general retail sector. Growth was stronger in the third and fourth quarters than in quarter two, showing that, I think that things are stabilizing and that the adjustments we've made to the prevailing environment has helped improve our competitiveness.

Tesco Direct saw strong growth at more than 50%. It's well on the way to becoming a substantial business, 10% more products in the new spring/summer catalogue, now 12,500 products on line. Clothing's being added later in the year. Our latest trial Homeplus store in Edinburgh and Nottingham features stocked in Direct and they've both beaten budgets, this combination of non-food only on display, but with a bigger range of stocked in Direct. They're doing well.

As you know we're putting more capital and management resources behind our successful Retailing Services, with the aim of taking them to the next level in terms of scale and materiality to the Group. I believe there won't be a better time to increase our commitment to Financial Services. Consumers are looking for a better deal and that's why Tesco is ideally placed to build a bigger presence by taking TPF from a popular collection of financial products to a full service Tesco bank.

We completed the TPF deal only in December, but the experienced and growing team there is getting on with the task of building our own systems platform, starting a branch network in Tesco stores and developing a broader range of products that will include a current account. Meanwhile the business is performing well. It saw a good growth in the year and the success of our new savings products, and we've been recently opening accounts at a thousand a day, means that the balance sheet is self-funded.

Dotcom has also been on good form with good sales and profits growth even after the startup costs on Direct. Telecoms has had a strong year. Tesco Mobile grew double-digit in a very flat prepay market, we're the only growing prepay operator. And its new pay monthly tariffs are proving very popular; also they also like our in-store telecom centers. In fact we're adding another 60 this year to bring the total to 100, so we're rolling those out very quickly.

The world around us is changing, but our focus on environment and on our communities does not. David's already talked to you about some of the things we're doing. Strategically this is important because it's still very important to our customers, and that means we'll continue to invest in encouraging green consumption, driving forward our community plans.

Tesco is doing what it can to help the economy in tough times because we're growing. We continue to invest right through the downturn. We're still creating jobs both in Tesco and in the enterprises that supply us. This year we're adding a total of 11.50 -- sorry, 11,000 new jobs in the UK, another 15,000 worldwide. And in the UK alone our capital spend, 1.5 billion sustains another 7,500 jobs in the construction industry.

So in summary, Tesco is about growth and our strategy for growth has given us momentum through this downturn. Our success has been based on listening to customers; as they change, we change. We're successfully adjusting our business and our approach for customers who have different priorities today. We've made a step-change with our wider responsibilities to the communities we serve, including on climate change, and our continued investment will make a real difference in tough times.

We're continuing to pursue and invest in our strategy ready to grasp the opportunities that tough times present. Well there's two concepts you're talking about, one is the transaction side of foreign currency exposure; the other is the balance sheet side of the exposure. If we deal firstly with the transactional side: so most of our non-food volume actually sits in euros, so it actually sits in distribution centers in Slovakia. We've got a very good hedge from dollars, which is originally bought in into euros in Slovakia. A lot of it comes through from Asia. And then we've got about four to five months of cover between euros into all the various currencies from florins to kroners. So, in transactional side I think we've actually got a potential profit and competitive upside going forward.

In terms of the balance sheet, it's very different. So when you hedge against your balance sheet all you're doing is you're taking the debt in an opposite currency and hoping that the assets and the loans or liabilities move up in the same proportion. Our policy is to hedge roughly 40% of our net assets in any country on all of our inter-company balances. And that avoids major movements in the P&L; it keeps the movements in the reserves.

We're pretty well hedged in terms of Hungary and Slovakia and the Czech Republic, and we've got a reasonable hedge in Poland.
